docs.lead_paragraph: At Thursday's rally for the House health care bill, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, hauled out the gavel he had used when he was in the speaker's chair on the day in 1965 when the House passed the Medicare bill. ''I'm going to lend it to whoever gets to preside over this legislation, because a good piece of wood doesn't wear out with one great event,'' Mr. Dingell declared, waving the mallet.
docs.abstract: Prescriptions blog entry notes Rep John D Dingell of Michigan's passing of historic gavel used in 1965 when House passed Medicare bill for first time; photo (M)
docs.snippet: At Thursday's rally for the House health care bill, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, hauled out the gavel he had used when he was in the speaker's chair on the day in 1965 when the House passed the Medicare bill.      ''I'm going...

docs.lead_paragraph: As health care legislation advances in Congress, the provisions most likely to become law are those that are identical or nearly so in the House and Senate measures. One such provision would require insurers to allow young adults to remain on their parents' policies -- until their 27th birthdays, under the House bill unveiled on Thursday, and at least until age 26 under the Senate version.
docs.abstract: Prescriptions blog entry on provision likely to be passed in both House and Senate versions of health care reform bill that would allow young adults to remain on parents' insurance policies until age 26 or 27; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers' reactions to the health care legislation proposed by House Democrats on Thursday ranged from cautious optimism to acid condemnation -- the latter from both ends of the political spectrum. A sampling of comments submitted to the Prescriptions blog: ''So when will someone tell the health insurance industry that making a profit by denying payments for health care benefits is no longer a viable business model for the United States?'' BacktoBasicsRob
docs.abstract: Sampling of reader comments on Prescriptions blog about health care reform debate; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After much agitation earlier in the day, the Senate voted to confirm Dr. Regina Benjamin as the nation's surgeon general on Thursday night amid a national emergency over the swine flu outbreak.
docs.abstract: Dr. Regina Benjamin was approved on a voice vote on Thursday evening.
